awd_titl_txt: An experimental study of rheology and microscopic dynamics of sheared active fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1702352
PI: Cheng, Xiang

This award will provide support to develop two new instruments to study the properties of active fluids. An active fluid is a suspension of particles in liquid that can generate their own motion and propel themselves. There are both synthetic and naturally-occurring active suspensions. This proposal will focus on suspensions of bacterial cells, which exhibit fascinating motions based on the coordinated behavior of many cells. The cells' motions cause these fluids to flow in new and unusual ways. An ultra-fast confocal microscope equipped with a chamber that can generate flow will be built at the University of Minnesota. This instrument will allow investigators to observe cellular motion on the scale of individual cells as well as detect coordinated structures that develop among the cells in flow. A thin-film rheometer will be built at Cal Poly - San Luis Obispo. This instrument will measure bulk properties of the active suspensions. The results of these experiments will help validate computational and theoretical studies of active suspensions. The instruments will also be useful for studying other complex fluids where microscopic arrangements of suspended particles influence the fluid dynamics of the suspension. The investigators will involve undergraduates in the research, including students from traditionally underrepresented groups in science and engineering. In addition, they will create new demonstrations of active suspensions to engage the public at the Minnesota State Fair and at Cal Poly's open house and pre-collegiate symposium. 

This project will reveal direct correlations between microscopic active particle dynamics and macroscopic flow behaviors of active suspensions. Specifically, the most-widely studied active suspension, that of E. coli, will be investigated. Two fundamental questions will be addressed. First, what is the dynamical origin of the superfluid phase of bacterial suspensions with extremely low or even zero apparent viscosity? Second, how does an externally imposed shear flow influence the dynamics of individual active particles in concentrated bacterial suspensions? Thus, the experiments will address two key questions underlying the predictions of theories of active suspensions. The experiments will unambiguously reveal the microscopic origin of unusual rheology of active fluids and provide a solid experimental foundation for the development of the field. Results from this project are expected to help practitioners find better ways to control transport in biological suspensions, prevent formation of biofilms, control viscosity in suspensions, and improve mixing in microfluidic devices used in bioassays and advanced materials synthesis.

por.por_cntn:
As a new class of soft materials, an active fluid is a dispersion of a large number of self-propelled units in a fluid medium. These self-propelled units use internal or ambient energy to drive the fluid into a nonequilibrium steady state, which displays various fascinating properties drastically different from those of conventional passive fluids. Examples of active fluids cover diverse natural and engineering systems including suspensions of bacteria, layers of moving epithelial cells, assays of motor-driven cytoskeletal filaments and suspensions of synthetic colloidal swimmers. Understanding the flow properties of active fluids is important not only for the fundamental study of the emergent phenomena of nonequilibrium systems but also for potential technical applications of active materials. Within this context, this research project aimed to investigate the unusual flow properties of active fluids using newly developed experimental techniques (i.e. fast confocal rheometry and interfacial rheometry) and reveal the microscopic origin of these unusual properties through the dynamics of individual self-propelled particles.

Our research consisted of two tasks. In the first task, Escherichia coli (E. coli) were used exclusively as self-propelled particles, which are often viewed as the prominent model of active fluids. We applied fast confocal microcopy and rheometry to probe the flow properties, especially the collective flow, of dense E. coli suspensions. In particular, we investigated the velocity profile of bacterial suspensions under shear and uncovered a symmetric shear banding structure in dense bacterial suspensions at low shear rates. Moreover, we measured the density and velocity fluctuations of bacterial suspensions and delineated the phase boundary between the disordered flow and the collective flow of the suspensions. The kinetic pathway towards bacterial collective flow was also examined. Lastly, we studied the dynamics of bacteria in complex fluids and showed the microscopic origin of bacterial speed enhancement in complex fluids. Taken together, the results of the first task revealed unexpected flow behaviors of bacterial suspensions and deepened our understanding of the emergent collective dynamics of active fluids.

Through the close collaboration between the two PIs, we have developed a new interfacial rheometer in the second task, which is suitable for the study of active fluids that exist at or near the interface between two non-active fluids. Specifically, we designed a new type of magnetic rod interfacial stress rheometer. The compact design of our rheometer allowed us to couple it with a commercial general-purpose microscope, which facilitated the simultaneous measurements of interfacial rheology (i.e. mechanical properties) and the dynamics of individual particles. Using the new rheometer, we studied the rheology and structure of particle-laden fluid interfaces made of the mixture of Janus particles and passive colloidal particles. As shown by previous studies, Janus particles become active when reacting with properly chosen solvents. Thus, the results of our second task paved the way for the study of the interfacial rheology of active fluids. More broadly, the new design of our interfacial rheometer is both lower-cost and highly adaptable, and it can be used by any laboratories that have access to optical microscopes for a wide range of interfacial systems beyond active fluids.  

Our work led to six publications in top journals including one in Nature, one in Science Advances and one in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America. The project partially supported three graduate students at University of Minnesota (UMN) and one postdoc at Penn State University. In addition, the project also provided funding for 7 undergraduate students at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo in conducting research, which included 4 students from underrepresented groups in STEM. The two research groups gave total 15 talks at seminars and conferences on the project. Supported by the project, the two PIs were also involved in several outreach activities including the participation of "Green Chemistry and Engineering" exhibition at the Minnesota State Fair (PI Cheng), serving as the faculty mentor of the UMN Energy Club (PI Cheng), giving a talk at a national conference for K-12 science teachers (co-PI Keim) and organizing lab tours for K-12 science teachers (co-PI Keim). Finally, the work from the project has been reported by more than 30 news media outlets, which raised public awareness of the importance of science and engineering.
